title: Grubhub massacre rounds out Caledonia trilogy
text:
“Much is made of intense competition in this space,” they dismissively noted, “but Grubhub financials tell a different story – one of consistent and predictable growth”. Ah, no, they just tell the story of intense competition.

“We are just entering the steepest part of the s-curve for market penetration now.” Is this s-curve the very latest in long drop dunnies?

Michael Messara, from Caledonia, during the UBS Investment Conference in 2016 Daniel Munoz/Fairfax Media

Cynically, Caledonia also measures GRUB’s earnings by normalising for its advertising spending, the equivalent of judging BHP’s after excluding its cost of mining.

Vicars’ best hope now is for Grubhub to be taken out by an Amazon, which took a stake in Deliveroo in May after shuttering Amazon Restaurants UK in December.

His style of highly-concentrated investing had been wildly successful until last year. Caledonia has nearly three-quarters of its funds under management in three positions: Grubhub, Zillow and The Stars Group.

In September 2018, Grubhub shares peaked at US$146.11. They’re now $33.11 (-77.3 per cent).

In June 2018, Zillow and Stars shares hit US$65.21 and US$37.80 respectively. They closed on Tuesday at US$33.46 (-48.7 per cent) and US$20.20 (-46.6 per cent).

Caledonia was buying at vastly lower prices than the peaks, of course, but its performance (and thus performance fees) is marked to market. Mercifully, Vicars doesn’t pay a 5 to 20 per cent underperformance fee back to his clients in years like these – or else he’d be selling his yacht! The market’s crueller wags have even taken to calling Messara “MayoshiSon”, for the SoftBank CEO and his run of catastrophic tech investments (our favourite being US$300 million on a dog walking app).

A less vocal Grubhub shareholder Down Under is VGI Partners, whose 13F filings show it with a US$49.9 million position, its 10th largest (in the US). Funnily enough, its executive chairman Rob Luciano is a Caledonia alumnus. And in Vicars’ pet, his and Doug Tynan’s clients have taken a $22 million single-session bath. About time they lost some bark, wouldn’t you say?
description: First there was Zillow, then Stars Group and now Grubhub. Will Vicars' nightmare is complete.
